choices.C: Execute this command as HR user in the DENVER database.
choices.A: Execute this command as HR user in the BOSTON database and SYS user in the DENVER database.
choices.D: Execute this command as HR user in the BOSTON database.
choices.B: Execute this command as SYS user in both the databases.

questions.question_text:
The HR schema exists in two databases, BOSTON and DENVER, and has the same password, HR.
You have the CREATE DATABASE LINK and CREATE SESSION privileges on both the database.
BOSTON is defined as a service name in the tnsnames.ora of both the databases.
You plan to use the command:
CREATE DATABASE LINK hr_link CONNECT to hr IDENTIFIED BY hr USING 'denver';
What must be done to ensure only the HR user in the BOSTON database can access the HR schema in the DENVER database?

discussion.content: Creating a link as HR user means link is owned by HR user and hence only HR user can access it. So answer is D

choices.D: The orcl TNS alias should be defined in the tnsnames.ora file on both the client and the database host.
choices.C: The orcl TNS alias should be defined such that it is resolvable by a client running on the database host.
choices.A: In the tnsnames.ora file, the SERVICE_NAME value of CONNECT_DATA should be explicitly suffixed with the domain name.
choices.E: The TNS_ADMIN environment variable should be set to orcl on the client.
choices.B: The SERVICE_NAMES initialization parameter should contain the name orcl in the database host.

questions.question_text:
Examine the command:

SQL> CONNECT hr/hr@orcl -
Which two configurations allow this command to execute successfully? (Choose two.)

comments.content: the service name in the listener not tns
no, domain name is not necessary

questions.question_text: Which users are created and can be used for database and host management of your DBaaS database servers?

discussion.content:
I agree A : https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/key-vault/18.4/okvag/okv_dbcs.html#GUID-1C6AD90B-938F-461A-B5A3-AB27E8D728E5
in the point: 12.2.3 Creating a Low Privileged Operating System User on Database as a Service
Recreating controlfile means resetlogs option is required as latest SCN changes, and has to be written to redo logs after resetting them.

choices.E: One control file copy is intact and damaged control file copies have to be restored to a non-default location.
choices.B: One control file copy is intact and damaged control file copies have to be restored to the default location.
choices.A: One control file copy is intact so the spfile is changed to refer to only one copy.
choices.C: All copies of the control file are damaged and the CREATE CONTROLFILE statement is executed manually.
choices.D: All copies of the control file are damaged and the auto backed up control file is used for recovery.

questions.question_text:
In your database, archive logging and control file autobackup are enabled.
The data files and redo log files are intact but control files are impacted due to media failure.
In which two recovery scenarios must you use the RESETLOGS option? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADE
Exports view emp_dept as a table with same data and columns as in the view.
The dump file will contain a table with the name emp_dept holding data from the view. 
Data Pump also exports objects dependent on the view, such as grants and constraints.

Selected Answer: ADE
Data Pump exports a table with the same columns as the view and with row data fetched from the view. Data Pump also exports objects dependent on the view, such as grants and constraints. Dependent objects that do not apply to tables (for example, grants of the UNDER object privilege) are not exported.The VIEWS_AS_TABLES parameter can be used by itself or along with the TABLES parameter. If either is used, Data Pump performs a table-mode export.

Selected Answer: CDE
I think C D E.
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/SUTIL/GUID-E4E45E81-5391-43BE-B27D-B763EF79A885.htm#SUTIL3904

questions.question_text:
Examine the command to perform a data pump export operation on a source database:
$> expdp hr/hr DIRECTORY=dumpdir DUMPFILE=emp1.dmp VIEWS_AS_TABLE=emp_dept
On the target database, you execute the data pump import command:
$> impdp hr/hr DIRECTORY=dumpdir DUMPFILE=emp1.dmp VIEWS_AS_TABLE=emp_dept
Which three statements are true? (Choose three.)

choices.B: The impdp operation creates the view and dependent objects.
choices.D: Objects dependent on the EMP_DEPT view are exported.
choices.C: All rows from the dependent objects, along with the metadata required to create the EMP_DEPT view, are exported.
choices.E: The impdp operation creates EMP_DEPT as table and populates it with the data from the export dump file.
choices.A: The expdp operation exports data that satisfies the condition of the defining query used to create the EMP_DEPT view.
